webTitle: Davos 2014: World Economic Forum - day one as it happened

fields.bodyText: Well, that was quite a dramatic speech from Shinzo Abe to the WEF -- delivered in pretty excellent English too (he switched to Japanese for a brief Q&A afterwards). The key points are. The Japanese PM called for restraint over military spending in Asia, where the ongoing dispute between Tokypo and Beijing over ownership of the Senkaku/Diaoyu uninhabited islands close to Taiwan, which are under Japan's control. Abe's warning that military expansion could go unchecked appears to be an appeal to leaders at Davos to support Japan over the dispute. Abe also announced new measures to get more women involved in the labour force, saying Japan could not afford not to. He will bring in legislation soon to set a target that 30% of leadership positions would be held by women by 2020. On economics, Abe said that Japan would soon emerge from deflation, with rising real wages feeding into the economy and stimulating productivity. He also pledged to keep fighting special interests, to deregulate the energy market and to cut corporation taxes again to encourage firms to invest.c BIG NEWS: Shinzo Abe concludes his speech to the World Economic Forum by calling for military restraint in Asia. The move comes after rising tension in the area with China over islands in the East China Sea. The Japanese PM says: We must restrain military expansion in Asia, which otherwise could go unchecked. Military spending must be transparent, and able to be verified. We must create a process for crisis management and lay down rules that enforce the international control of the sea, he continues. Only then can we get growth and prosperity in Asia. Japan has sworn an oath, never again to wage a war. We continue to wish the world will remain in peace. And he sincerely hope that through Abenomics we can create economic growth, which will result in lasting peace in the region. Japan was touched by support of the world following the Fukishima disaster, Abe says - and the challenge of rebuilding and recovering is not over. Shinzo Abe declares that he will bring forward legislation soon, setting targets to get many more women into senior positions in Japanese companies. He says Japan will have 30% of top positions filled by women by 2020 -- that's a challenging target, but one which Abe says can deliver big benefits. He cites Arianna Huffington's quote about how Lehman Brothers would have survived if it had been Brothers and Sisters. And adds that Hilary Clinton has told him that Japan's economy could grow 16% faster if women were fully engaged in it. Abe declares: Japan must become a place where women shine. The Japanese PM is gunning for special interests, saying that "I am willing to act like a drill bit to break through the solid rock of vested interests." Abe also pledges to keep shaking up the tax system. Abe begins by joking that he doesn't know who coined the term Abenomics, but he'll have to use his own name to describe his policiesfor a bit longer. He then declares that Japan is poised to break free from the chronic deflation that has gripped it for so many years, declaring: High wages, long overdue will lead to increased productivity. Japan is now getting on track for fiscal consolidation, he adds. Our growth rate has changed dramatically, from negative to positive, he continues, pointing to g to the Olympics and Paralympics coming soon. A new dawn is breaking over Japan Abe continues - we will liberalise the energy markets, and we will allow private firms to break into farming. Shinzo Abe is being introduced at Davos now, with WEF founder Klaus Schwab declaring that, thanks to his bold economic and monetary reforms, he can say that Japan is Back. We need more bold ideas like Abenomics, Schwab adds. Bloomberg's Francine Lacqua has tweeted a great photo showing the aeroplanes on which the Israeli and Iranian delegations flew in for WEF -- side by side. It's nearly time for the big set-piece event of the day - a special address by Japan's prime minister, Shinzo Abe. The congress hall is filling up.... Philip Jennings of UNI Global Union also believes some Davos delegates have woken up to the scale of the inequality problem gripping the global economy, saying: They're now worried about social tensions, unemployment, and the unfair distribution of wealth. The other important issue, he adds, is that the public have a complete lack of confidence that this generation's political classes understand the life of an ordinary worker. Just grabbed a few minute with Davos veteran Philip Jennings, general secretary of the UNI Global Union. He's delighted that the Pope shook up Davos with a hard-hitting message last night to reflect on the causes of the economic crisis, and to help build a new economic order where wealth serves the people not the other way round (Larry Elliott has blogged about the Pope's 'leftie message' here). It's Pope Francis's latest interjection into the debate on reforming capitalism - and Jennings reckons it has really made an impact on WEF this year, right at the start of the Forum, joking: Our new Argentinian striker has delivered - he's scored a goal in the second minute of the game. This year's Davos theme is all about reshaping the global economy -- and the Pope has thrown down the challenge to actually deliver, not just talk. Jennings explained: If WEF were looking for a Papal blessing, then they didn't get it. They didn't get absolution either -- the message they got from the Pope was 'Do better, I'm watching'. UK banking chiefs are telling Davos that the financial markets are safer than back in 2009, but not everyone is convinced they they've learned their lessons. At a debate called "Are markets safer now", HSBC's chairman Douglas Flint said his bank had thrown much more resources at ensuring it is complying with the law. Barclays boss Antony Jenkins argued that the issue goes beyond just banks. Jill tweets the key points: Paul Singer, CEO and co-chief investment officer of fund manager Elliott Management, is also on the panel -- and cautioned that banks are still involved in exotic products that could rebound on them: Jenkins argues that the key is to keep bankers' animal spirits in check: Alpha Condé, president of Guinea, spoke at a session on mineral extraction a few minute ago, and accused Western lawyers of using trickery to steal natural resources from his country in the past. He said the corrupt theft of natural resources was aided by the west, and its lawyers expertise in terms of legal tricks. Conde said: A lot of the transparency that was not present, was made possibly by legal tricks and the use of financial havens where people were able to hide their funds. But he said the situation was now improving, as Guinea was getting support from the World Bank, the African Development Bank, and a number of western countries including the UK, the US, France and switzerland. I am more optimistic about the situation, he concluded. (via Larry Elliott) 3D printing has captured the attention of WEF delegates, with a large crowd forming to watch a demonstration of how the modelling and fabrication process works. Neil Gershenfeld of the Fab Lab drew a cube on a screen, then a sphere, and used one to manipulate the shape of the other. He then niftily reshaped them, using a tool that was 'resisted' by the shapes to make a more intricate design. The gathering even attracted Sir Tim Berner-Lee, the father of the web, who positioned himself in front of the screen and took copious notes. Now there's a man who can spot an important technology.... Bill Browder, the veteran hedge fund boss, has predicted that Vladimir Putin's government would collapse within a year if the price of oil fell to $60 a barrel. A barrel of Brent Crude is £107 a barrel, somewhat below the $117 figure oil-dependent Russia relies on to balance its budget. Speaking to the Daily Telegraph in Davos, Browder described himself as "Putin's no 1 enemy". He has led a global campaign to bring to punish the top Kremlin officials he sees as responsible for the death of his lawyer, Sergei Magnitsky. (Background here). All it will take is a fall in the price of oil to $60 a barrel and Putin will be gone within a year. You'd be surprised how brittle the system really is. Browder also had a warning for investors piling into other fast-growing markets, the BRICs or Mints. Lot of ill-informed money went into these countries during the credit boom. The next big thing coming is that some of these countries will start to close their capital accounts. We're already seeing it in Egypt and Brazil in different ways. This could start a chain-reaction, he said. People will start asking themselves which country is next. Once this start people may find they can't get their money out again. JR More on Vince Cable, with an intriguing report from Sky News that the business secretary plans to block a pay increase for the chief executive of the newly-privatised Royal Mail. The row over pay has been simmering since last weekend, reports Sky, when Donald Brydon, Royal Mail's chairman, told the Sunday Telegraph that increasing Moya Greene's pay was necessary if the company wanted to keep her. Describing her as the “lowest paid chief executive in the FTSE100”, he said: I think it’s only fair to pay Moya the right market rate for her job. Now Cable is said to be ready to use his vote to block any increase. This comes after Greene was forced to hand back a £250,000 housing allowance last year, prompting her to bemoan "the hopelessly broken" system for setting executive pay. JR Democratic dividend”, at least so far, is the catchiest phrase of the session on Africa in reference to the improved democracy across the continent (writes Jill Treanor). Even so Oxfam's Winnie Byanyima took the opportunity to remind participants of the research put out the charity just as the WEF was beginning, that people are being trapped in a cycle of poverty. “The 85 wealthiest people in the world own the same wealth as half the population of the world, there is something wrong with that because it is immoral." Julian Roberts, boss of London-listed insurer Old Mutual, was sporting what looked to be a South African flag scarf, said he wouldn't be investing in Africa if there were not opportunities – 50% of the people are under 20. But there were problems – one infrastructure project Old Mutual funded was subsequently nationalised. “Africa cannot exist without a handshake between private enterprise and the public sector,” said Roberts. He also called for changes in visa requirements and import controls -pointing to the month it can take to get goods and services out of west Africa. Aliko Dangote, a leading Nigerian businessman through his Dangote Group, lamented the lack of trade within Africa, currently just 11% of the total trade. As a Nigerian he said he needed 38 visas to move around the continent making it easier for Americans to move around and do business. The president of Nigeria, Goodluck Elebe Jonathan, who was asked about the oil that “disappears” each year from the oil-rich Niger Delta. He insisted was not due to corruption. Vince Cable has said the UK is seeing "spectacular improvements" to productivity in key manufacturing sectors, but faces "serious problem" if this was not spread more broadly across the economy. Speaking at the House of Common's business, innovation and skills select committee, the business secretary said productivity had to improve. We have a serious problem if it continues but actually the poor productivity performance is a flipside of having a relatively favourable performance on employment. We are working with some of the key industries - aerospace, cars, biosciences, supply chains for energy and others - and lot of the work around innovation and skill training and supply chain rebuilding is about improving British productivity. You are now seeing spectacular improvements in productivity in some of those key manufacturing sectors. It hasn't happened through the rest of the economy. I've taken quotes from the Press Association. A couple more photos from this morning's sessions The Office for Budget Responsibility has issued its comment on figures showing a drop in government borrowing. The implicit message for the chancellor is 'don't celebrate too soon'. The 2013-14 PSNB [Public Sector Net Borrowing] forecast remains uncertain. Tax receipts will depend in part on the performance of the economy over the remainder of the year, but there are additional uncertainties, such as the tax expected from financial sector bonuses and the extent to which receipts from self-assessment (SA) income tax are affected by the reduction in the additional rate of income tax to 45p. And on the spending side, much will depend on departments’ surrenders of underspends in their supplementary estimates (usually published in February) and the extent to which those estimates are in turn underspent. Central and local government monthly expenditure outturns are also prone to revision well after the end of the financial year. Worth bearing in mind, because the ONS figures are estimates subject to revision. JR Sir Richard Branson has been taking part at another lunch event, on the 2030 agenda for progress in the developing world. It was billed as a private lunch, but some details are being tweeted -- with the Telegraph's Kamal Ahmed reporting that Branson called for penalties for drugs offences to be relaxed: Oxfam's Greenpeace International Executive Director, Kumi Naidoo, was also on the panel and reports that Branson called on Davos attendees to "replace dirty business with clean business". Matt Damon and Gary White of Water.org were also attending-- last night, Damon explained that they hope to raise money in Davos today to fund more micro loans to people in the developing world who need a supply of clean water. Gilt yields have continued to climb after the big fall in UK unemployment. At 12:30 they were up six basis points at 2.895%. The rise took the spread between British and German interest rates to its widest in more than eight years, Reuters reported. Investors are betting on a rate rise in the UK whereas talk in the eurozone is of whether the ECB will loosen monetary policy. Hence the widening gap between the rate investors will accept to buy UK and German government bonds in the market. Sterling rose to a one-year high against the euro, too. Economists at Citi have moved their target date for a UK rate rise to the final quarter of this year from their earlier forecast of the second quarter of 2015. Plenty there for the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee to ponder. SF There wasn't much jubilation among the Davos panel at the session on the Global Financial Outlook this morning. Ray Dalio, founder of Bridgewater Associates, said the US economy has hit a dull rut, and also predicted that emerging markets will suffer as capital continues to flow out. Joe Weisenthal of Business Insider tweeted the key points: And Standard Chartered CEO Peter Sands echoed a point being made in the session on the European recovery - May's elections could change the picture: Jennifer has handed over to me, Sean Farrell, for a while. I wrote the Greece post just now. Greece's highest administrative court has overruled pay cuts for the police and armed forces imposed by the government in 2012, Reuters reports. The decision could create a €500m gap in the country's finances, causing further complications for talks between Greece and its lenders over more rescue loans, the report said. The ruling hasn't been made public but was confirmed by officials, Reuters said. The 10% cut was judged unconstitutional because as a core part of the state they warrant protection, an official told the agency. SF Even the powerbrokers of Davos stop for lunch, and today they're tucking into a buffet feast hosted by the government of Nigeria (writes GW, on a laptop propped up on a pile of mangos and pineapples). Much bantering is taking place between delegates, while a looped video hails Nigeria's many economic opportunities (a growing middle class, big oil reserves etc). No mention of human rights concerns, alas. Shrugging off the latest fall in unemployment, the FTSE 100 index is down 0.08% at 6828 points. According to Reuters, this marks a step back from an 8-month peak, with companies unsettled about rate rises. JR Nouriel Roubini, the economist who forecast that a housing slump would cause an economic crash, is making more eye-catching predictions at Davos. JR That session on whether Europe was "back" from the brink of crisis ended with Accenture's top man in France, Pierre Nanterme, criticising Europe's leaders for fueling extremist political groups. Nanterme said he was "extremely concerned" about the European elections, given the rise of extreme parties in Europe riding on the back of record unemployment. He said European leaders and policymakers were to blame for failing to address people's fears over inequality and employment, issues that are "entirely absent" from the technical debate about Europe. People "want a job, they want inclusion and diversity within Europe", Nanterme said. Trade Union leaders have welcomed the fall in UK unemployment, but sounded notes of caution. Frances O’Grady, general secretary of the TUC, described the big fall in unemployment as encouraging. But while headline unemployment is within a whisker of the Bank’s forward guidance threshold, an early interest rate rise would clobber mortgage holders and businesses – jeopardising our economic recovery. Patchy levels of jobs growth in parts of the north and the continuing squeeze on living standards should make the Bank of England think twice before considering a rate raise. The TUC’s latest economic report found that the likelihood of being in work has fallen in the North East, North West, West Midlands and South West since mid-2010, despite the number of people in work increasing by around 780,000 across the UK. Len McCluskey, Unite's general secretary, had a message for the Low Pay Commission, soon to issue its recommendations on the minimum wage. Britain’s workers need a decent pay rise so that wages are not continually eroded by inflation. Unite has repeatedly called for the national minimum wage to be raised by £1.50 an hour from the current £6.31 – and we urge the Low Pay Commission to make that recommendation. To put in it perspective, the UK has one of the highest rates of personal debt in Europe, millions are working for poverty wages and thousands of people rely on food banks to put a meal on the table for their family, yet the stock market is performing well. Companies can well afford to be more generous when it comes to paying more to their workers. JR The former Cabinet secretary Lord Gus O'Donnell is in Davos trying to raise awareness about mental health. O'Donnell heads the WEF's council on well being and mental health, and says policy makers and business need to tackle the issue. He told Larry Elliott that: "One in four members of the workforce suffers from some of mental health problem and the benefits of picking up problems early are considerable. Problems are treatable." O'Donnell says there are three big benefits of early action: a much-smaller NHS bill for anti-depressants; fewer people on disability benefits and preventing people from losing precious employment skills. "This is a big issue, but nobody talks about it", he added. Over in Brussels, the EU executive has called on Europe to cut its carbon emissions by 40% by 2030, compared to 1990 levels. The 40% target still has to be written into law, a lengthy process that involves the EU's 28 member states and the European Parliament. The European Commission has also called for a 27% of Europe's energy to come from renewable energy by 2030, and for energy savings of 25%. For full coverage go to the Guardian's environment blog. JR The politics of interest-rate decisions... JR Amid all the drama over the unemployment data, let's not overlook an improvement in the UK public finances. Government borrowing fell to £12.1bn in December, down £2.1bn from last year. The figure excludes bank bailouts. You can see the full Office for National Statistics data set here. JR Sir Tim Berners-Lee made a surprise intervention "from the floor" into a Davos debate about Big Brother and a conversation about haystacks – bundles of data being collected by the governments, reports Jill Treanor. "When you are operating at this level you have no idea if these people are American citizens or been suspected of committing some sort of crime,” the father of the web said. Lots of the data isn't used and Berners-Lee called for a discussion about what the information is used for. We need to talk about even if you do get the data what can you use it for. Is it data you could use for someone taking out an insurance policy, what types of things... Larry Elliott, the Guardian's economics editor, thinks the Bank of England will be re-writing its forward guidance policy, after unemployment fell faster than expected. Here is a sneak preview of his analysis. Unemployment is falling fast. In the quarter ending in November, the jobless total saw its biggest drop since modern records began. The jobless rate is currently 7.1% and will hit the Bank of England’s threshold for contemplating an interest rate rise next month. Does this mean that Threadneedle Street seriously underestimated the strength of the labour market? Yes it does. Will Mark Carney have to announce a change to the Bank’s forward guidance strategy next month? Yes he will. Is an increase in the cost of borrowing imminent? No it isn’t. Let’s take those points one by one. Back in August, when Carney announced forward guidance, the Bank said that by early 2016 there was still a 50% chance that unemployment would be above 7%. By November, the Bank thought the jobless rate would get to 7% by 2015. Now it looks like it will do so before the end of 2013. That, to put it mildly, is a big forecasting error, albeit not the first the Bank has been guilty of in recent years. The minutes of the December meetings of the monetary policy committee shows that the latest figure came as little surprise to Threadneedle Street, noting that the 7% threshold would be reached “materially earlier” than expected in the Bank’s November inflation report. As to what Carney does now, it would be daft to expect the governor to junk the big policy change he initiated after taking over from Mervyn King back in the summer. Nor does it seem all that likely that after just six months, Carney will move to the much looser form of forward guidance used by the Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank, where policy makers gauge whether the economy is strong enough to withstand higher interest rates. Instead, the most likely outcome is that the 7% threshold will be dropped to 6.5%. That would leave the principle of forward guidance intact while adjusting to changed circumstances. More to follow here JR Harvard professor Ken Rogoff does pay credit to Europe's politicians for being "light years" ahead of Washington in realising the scale of the problem in inequality,and the labour force's shrinking share of the pie. More progressive taxation will be needed to rebalance the situation, he suggests. And if Europe takes too long to tackle its problems, it may wake up from its slumbers to find it's a lot smaller in globaal terms. Following a larger than expected fall in unemployment, economists are not expecting a change to interest rates anytime soon. Jeremy Cook, chief economist at currency company World First, thinks the odds are against a rate rise, for "three good reasons". The Bank of England has been eager in these minutes to emphasise that productivity growth has been ‘disappointing’. They will likely use this as a reason for keeping policy very loose despite unemployment falling below the 7% threshold alongside. Wages – despite the recent anecdotal data from PMIs and some companies, especially in the services sector, that wage pressure is building we are still waiting for the 3m average to get back above 1.0% let alone CPI at 2.0%. Rate hikes are unlikely to be popular in an environment of falling real wages. Lastly, we’re looking at the pound. The Bank of England has expressed concerns of late in the run higher of GBP. Moves to raise rates and tighten policy will be a shot in the arm for an already overvalued currency; a killer for any ‘export-driven-march-of-the-makers’. In a killer line, he adds: As it stands at the moment forward guidance is proving to be exactly what everyone believes it to be; a policy that allows for further loose monetary policy and reflation of a credit bubble. Samuel Tombs at Capital Economics, agrees there will be no rate rise. We think that there is a strong chance that the Committee will alter its forward guidance alongside next month’s inflation report in order to provide the recovery with more support. Howard Archer at IHS, thinks unemployment is unlikely to improve at such a fast pace in future. The recent rate of improvement in the labour market has been both impressive and surprising, but we are dubious that unemployment will keep falling at such a rapid rate... We also anticipate that employment growth will increasingly be limited by increasing productivity as many companies are able to make greater use of the workers they already have. The fall in the unemployment is also likely to be limited by an expanding labour pool and by further job losses in the public sector. The workforce is expected to be lifted by some people returning to the jobs market as the overall improved economic environment makes them more optimistic about getting jobs. It may also be that a significant number of more confident companies are now taking on workers earlier than they really need them – in anticipation that the UK really is set for a period of sustained, healthy growth, and to ensure that they get potentially the best staff available. If this a significant factor, it would also suggest that the growth in employment will moderate over the coming months. He also thinks interest rates will stay unchanged at 0.5% until mid 2015. JR Axel Weber hammers home his point about Europe's weak recovery, saying that the speed at which it's now growing "still feels like a crisis". He told a packed room at Davos (highlights start here) that: The economy is too weak to sustain the kind of growth in jobs we need to get out of this crisis. Europe is also vulnerable to cutting-edge technologies such as 3D printing, Sorrell warns, which allow companies to cut their workforces. The Bank of England is getting a fair bit of stick for its dodgy economic forecasting. The shifting economic data puts the bank's forward guidance policy under strain - a pledge to hold interest rates until unemployment falls to 7%. The bank now says there is no immediate need to raise interest rates, even if unemployment falls to 7%. From the minutes of the monetary policy committee: Looking beyond the immediate policy decision, the Committee noted that while the recovery was becoming more firmly entrenched, productivity growth had been disappointing, and unemployment had fallen faster than expected. Inflation had returned to the 2% target, however, and cost pressures were subdued. Members therefore saw no immediate need to raise Bank Rate even if the 7% unemployment threshold were to be reached in the near future. Moreover, it was likely that the headwinds to growth associated with the aftermath of the financial crisis would persist for some time yet and that inflationary pressures would remain contained. Consequently when the time did come to raise Bank Rate, it would be appropriate to do so only gradually. The MPC also points out that weak pay growth "pointed to the continued existence of slack in the labour market". So unemployment has some way further to fall. JR Axel Weber of UBS (ex-Bundesbank) says the risks facing Europe have receded, but the region could face new upheaval this year. European growth rates are too weak, he warns, saying: The mood in financial markets may have improved, but the economic situation in many European countries will not improve. Weber says there are two threats -- May's European elections which could see more extremist parties enter the European Parliament, and possibly act like the US Tea Party.... ...and Europe's upcoming asset quality review (stress-testing eurozone banks). That test is meant to be an exam, and to be a credible exam someone needs to fail it, argues Weber. That could lead to market turbulence as speculators try to bet which banks will be winners or losers. Ken Rogoff tells Davos that the easing of the eurozone crisis is the single biggest reason for the pick-up in the global economy. But the "really horrific" youth unemployment stats are a big worry - Europe is an aging society, and it's losing the valuable resource of its youth. Sir Martin Sorrell and Ken Rogoff have agreed that Europe is stronger than a year ago, but still faces deep problems -- particularly its youth unemployment crisis. Sorrell told the "Is Europe Back?" session that he was "very bullish" about Germany and Poland, and also Russia. The IMF's new forecasts (yesterday) also give hope to George Osborne and David Cameron ahead of next year's election. "The bookends of Europe", UK and Germany, are doing well, says Sorrell. But three countries worry him - France (still on the downstroke of the U, says Sorrell), Italy (bumping on the bottom) and Spain (on the upturn, but with unacceptably high levels of unemployment). Sorrell adds: You cannot have a situation where 50% of your young people are out of work... it is politically and socially unacceptable. The social implications of unemployment are extremely critical, he adds. UK workers continue to see their wages lag behind prices. While inflation is running at 2.1%, average pay (excluding bonuses) had gone up 0.9%. But this masks a disparity between public and private sector workers. Private sector pay was up 1.1%, compared to 0.3% in the public sector. JR The jobs story in a bar chart. JR Here is some of the chatter on Twitter on the UK unemployment figures and BoE minutes: And from Treasury secretary Danny Alexander: JR So what does the Bank of England do now? UK unemployment has fallen faster than expected, good news for the economy (and chancellor George Osborne), but raising questions over the BoE's commitment to freeze interest rates, until unemployment falls below 7%. More details: The UK's unemployment rate has dropped to 7.1% in the three months to November 2013, a total of 2.32m jobless compared to 2.48m for the preceding quarter (ILO measures). Average weekly earnings were up 0.9% in the period The claimant count fell by 24,000 in December. The Bank of England's monetary committee policy has said unemployment will hit the 7% threshold "materially earlier" than forecast. The MPC minutes also show that the bank voted 9.0 to keep bond buying programme at 375 bn. In response Sterling is up against the dollar to $1.6553 UK 10-yr gilt yields have risen to 2.854% JR Back in Davos, a group including Axel Weber (former Bundesbank president and current chairman of UBS), economist Ken Rogoff and advertising chief Sir Martin Sorrell are holding a debate titled: Is Europe Back? (that's back from the brink of eurozone calamity and recession woes). It's being streamed here. Breaking news: UK unemployment falls to 7.1%, significantly better than expected. JR As promised - here's the story of how several technology CEOs have told Davos that fundamental legal changes need to be made in the light of the Edward Snowden/NSA revelations. Jill Treanor reports from this morning's session on "The New Digital Context" The boss of BT admitted on Wednesday that customers could not be guaranteed 100% privacy when using the internet or mobile devices and called for changes to “murky” laws on data collection. Speaking at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Gavin Patterson addressed the issues throw into open by the Guardian's investigation into the NSA through the whistleblower Edward Snowden. Asked if he wanted more laws, Patterson, who became the boss of BT recently, said: “Exactly, making it clear. It's just too murky at the moment it needs to be transparent and needs to be clear guidelines about what's acceptable and what isn't, Paterson said. “The legislation has to catch up . This is a challenge for the many different parts of our business models, it's often several years behind. It's not fit for purpose today. Everybody recognises the internet plays a role in protection us and we've got to make sure it's not intrusive and also protects the rights to the individual. I don't think the legislation has managed to keep up”. Could there be 100% privacy? “I think that's unlikely and I think that's [would mean] zero security,” Patterson. President Barack Obama on Friday announced reforms to the NSA, ending government storage of phone data and sparking fresh debate about the way data is collected. Marissa Mayer, the boss of Yahoo, told attendees in Davos it should be clear what data is being disclosed. She said: “What's murky about some of what is happing today is people don't necessary know what data is being collected and about what is being used.". She added that “2014 will be a tipping point.... it will change everyone's daily routines very fundamentally". The chairman and chief executive of Cisco, John Chambers, called for co-operation. He said: “We're not a service provider...we don't share our code with anyone. We come at it from a different perspective. We need rules of the road that everyone can live with... We need all companies to come up with general guidelines.... Countries need to work together to solve these issues, he said. Bill Gates, who is expected to be at Davos, has been making some big predictions. The billionaire philanthropist thinks there will be almost no poor countries left in the world by 2035. More than 70% of countries will have a higher income than China does today, while child mortality in developing countries will fall sharply. In the Gates Foundation's annual letter, he and his wife Melinda, tackle head on "the myth that poor countries are doomed to stay poor. I am optimistic enough about this that I am willing to make a prediction. By 2035, there will be almost no poor countries left in the world. (I mean by our current definition of poor*). Almost all countries will be what we now call lower-middle income or richer. Countries will learn from their most productive neighbours and benefit from innovations like new vaccines, better seeds, and the digital revolution. Their labour forces, buoyed by expanded education, will attract new investments. *Specifically, I mean that by 2035, almost no country will be as poor as any of the 35 countries that the World Bank classifies as low-income today, even after adjusting for inflation. A few countries will be held back by war, politics (North Korea, barring a big change there), or geography (landlocked nations in central Africa). And inequality will still be a problem: There will be poor people in every region. But most of them will live in countries that are self-sufficient. Every nation in South America, Asia, and Central America (with the possible exception of Haiti), and most in coastal Africa, will have joined the ranks of today’s middle-income nations. More than 70% of countries will have a higher per-person income than China does today. Nearly 90% will have a higher income than India does today. It will be a remarkable achievement. When I was born, most countries in the world were poor. In the next two decades, desperately poor countries will become the exception rather than the rule. Billions of people will have been lifted out of extreme poverty. The idea that this will happen within my lifetime is simply amazing to me. The Gates couple also identify two other myths about poverty. Bill Gates is concerned that the notion that “foreign aid is a waste of money”, which he says is often based on anecdotal evidence, and gives governments an excuse to slash aid budgets. [Aid] saves and improves lives very effectively, laying the groundwork for the kind of long-term economic progress The third myth the couple identify is that "saving lives leads to overpopulation". "This kind of thinking has gotten the world into a lot of trouble," writes Melinda Gates. JR Union leader Philip Jennings, who heads up UNI Global Union, has been criticising the sinners of the world economy in CNBC's TV studio. He tweets his best lines: CNBC is excited by Marissa Mayer's declaration that mobile traffic will have overtaken PC traffic by the end of the year. Mayer (who's one of the co-chairs of Davos this year) has been talking enthusiastically about how mobile innovation will help to make this a crucial year for the tech sector. The technology chief executives on this morning's panel are being quizzed about the National Security agency spying scandal. John Chambers of Cisco is arguing that there needs to be "co-operation" beween tech firms and the NSA, while BT's Gavin Patterson says that the existing laws are too murky. This follows revelations, in the documents leaked by Edward Snowden, that the NSA had access to the data collected by some of the world's biggest technology companies. We should have the quotes shortly: By the end of 2014, Yahoo! will be handling more traffic from mobile devices than from desktops, says Mayer - an example of why "the world's biggest start-up" needs to keep innovating. An interesting story from the Financial Times, which reports that Britain's banks have warned against a loss of UK influence in the European Union. In a submission to the government, the British Bankers’ Association said the balance of competence between the EU and UK was “broadly appropriate”. In a separate intervention, Jim Cowles, Citi Bank's chief executive for Europe, the Middle East and Asia, told the FT of “mounting concern” among clients about their ability to continue using the UK as a regional hub if the country were to exit. It’s not that international companies will stop investing in Britain, but their investment just won’t be at the scale we have become accustomed to. Almost on cue, the boss of Unilever, the consumer goods giant that makes PG Tips tea and Magnum ice cream, warns that it could cut its investment in the UK in the event of an EU exit. Paul Polman, chief executive of the Anglo Dutch conglomerate, said: We tend to forget all the good things that the common market has brought, also to Britain, and take that for granted and then only focus on the things that need to be changed and portraying that as bad. EU exit could see Unilever cut investment in UK JR Good morning from London, where we have a packed day of economic news. Official statistics out at 9.30 are expected to show a fall in UK unemployment, to around 7.3%, or even 7.2%, from 7.4%. Good news for everyone, but a headache for the Bank of England. If as expected, unemployment continues to fall, this will put pressure on the Bank to change or even abandon, its forward guidance policy, under which interest rates are frozen until unemployment has fallen to 7%. UK unemployment challenge for Carney as jobless rate expected to fall We are also looking out for the Bank of England minutes and UK borrowing figures for December. Elsewhere, the UK energy regulator has issued a stinging rebuke to RWE NPower for getting its figures wrong. Ofgem accused NPower of publishing “misleading” figures about the cost of transporting its energy. From the BBC In its analysis, Npower said the cost of transporting gas and electricity - so-called network costs - was likely to rise by 74% by 2020, pushing up household bills. Between 2015 and 2020, it claimed network costs would increase from £295 per customer to £314. But Ofgem, which regulates that side of the industry - and sets the price controls - said those figures were wrong. It said that after this year network costs per household "are expected to remain broadly flat in real terms". JR 2014 will be the "tipping point" year for digital technologies, Mayer adds. The session on the digital future is quite lively -- it began with the crowd of CEOs being asked to name a gadget that changed their life. No points for BT's Gavin Patterson, who couldn't name one. But Marissa Mayer cited her smartphone, while Marc Benioff of Salesforce.com named his FitBit exercise device. If (unlike RBS) you couldn't make it to Davos this week, you can track a lot of the action on the World Economic Forum's own website: WEF Live. Trudging through the snow last night, we were slightly surprised to spot that Royal Bank of Scotland (the bank saved from oblivion by the UK taxpayer) has set up a home-from-home in the heart of Davos. Complete with computer screens, comfy-looking sofas, and a counter groaning under fruit juices and pastries. That sort of operation doesn't come cheap at WEF. RBS, though, insists that it's a good investment: RBS is the biggest backer of UK businesses and plays a key role in helping corporates access international markets. That is why the bank needs to have a presence at events like Davos that are important for our clients. Cow bells are ringing across the Congress Centre (heck, this is Switzerland), which means the first sessions are underway -- there's quite a scrum to hear what Marissa Mayer et all have to say about the Digital World. Lots on in Davos today - here's a few highlights to watch out for. 9am Davos time (8am GMT): Tech CEOs including Yahoo's Marissa Mayer, BT's Gavin Patterson and Salesforce.com's Marc Benioff debate "The New Digital Context". 10.45am: A discussion on "Is Europe Back?" including Axel Weber, Kenneth Rogoff, and Sir Martin Sorrell 1.45pm: "Africa's next billion", with Oxfam's Winnie Byanyima, Nigeria's president Goodluck Jonathan, and Nigeria's billionaire businessman Aliko Dangote. 5.45pm: Japanese prime minister Shinzo Abe gives a special address on "The reshaping of the world: Vision from Japan". Good morning from Davos, Switzerland, where the 44th annual meeting of the World Economic Forum is getting underway. Around 2,500 delegates, including scores of world leaders, are attending WEF over the next four days, to discuss and debate a wide range of issues - from risks to the global economy to the ongoing humanitarian crisis in Syria. The overarching theme of the meeting, which will take place until 25 January, is: 'The Reshaping of the World: Consequences for Society, Politics and Business' A bold title, recognising the seismic changes that have rattled the global economy over the last six years.... ....but can those attending the temple of globalisation actually deliver results, given their role in creating the situation we face today? Last night, at the welcome ceremony, Davos founder Klaus Schwab urged delegates to bring their brains, souls, hearts and good nerves to make progress. The congress hall then rang to the stern words of Pope Francis who (through an envoy) urged Davosites to deliver "a new, profound, sense of responsibility", adding: The growth of equality … calls for decisions, mechanisms and processes directed to a better distribution of wealth, the creation of sources of employment and an integral promotion of the poor, which goes beyond a simple welfare mentality. (see last night's liveblog for the details). I'm here with my colleagues Larry Elliott and Jill Treanor, and between us we'll try to cover as much of the event as possible. Jennifer Rankin back in London will cover other important breaking news through the day too.
fields.standfirst:
All the action from Davos as the 44th meeting of the World Economic Forum got under way

  • Tech bosses call for changes following Snowden/NSA revelations
  • Euro elections and stress tests risks for 2014
  • UK unemployment falls sharply to 7.1%
  • No immediate need to raise rates says BoE
fields.byline: Graeme Wearden in Davos and Jennifer Rankin
fields.headline: Davos 2014: World Economic Forum - day one as it happened
fields.body:
6.13pm GMT

Well, that was quite a dramatic speech from Shinzo Abe to the WEF -- delivered in pretty excellent English too (he switched to Japanese for a brief Q&A afterwards).

The key points are.

The Japanese PM called for restraint over military spending in Asia, where the ongoing dispute between Tokypo and Beijing over ownership of the Senkaku/Diaoyu uninhabited islands close to Taiwan, which are under Japan's control.

Abe's warning that military expansion could go unchecked appears to be an appeal to leaders at Davos to support Japan over the dispute.

Abe also announced new measures to get more women involved in the labour force, saying Japan could not afford not to. He will bring in legislation soon to set a target that 30% of leadership positions would be held by women by 2020.

On economics, Abe said that Japan would soon emerge from deflation, with rising real wages feeding into the economy and stimulating productivity.

He also pledged to keep fighting special interests, to deregulate the energy market and to cut corporation taxes again to encourage firms to invest.c

5.30pm GMT

Japanese PM calls for military restraint in Asia

BIG NEWS: Shinzo Abe concludes his speech to the World Economic Forum by calling for military restraint in Asia.

The move comes after rising tension in the area with China over islands in the East China Sea. 

The Japanese PM says:

We must restrain military expansion in Asia, which otherwise could go unchecked.

Military spending must be transparent, and able to be verified.

We must create a process for crisis management and lay down rules that enforce the international control of the sea, he continues.

Only then can we get growth and prosperity in Asia.

Japan has sworn an oath, never again to wage a war.

We continue to wish the world will remain in peace.

And he sincerely hope that through Abenomics we can create economic growth, which will result in lasting peace in the region.

Updated at 5.58pm GMT

5.22pm GMT

Japan was touched by support of the world following the Fukishima disaster, Abe says - and the challenge of rebuilding and recovering is not over.

5.21pm GMT

Shinzo Abe declares that he will bring forward legislation soon, setting targets to get many more women into senior positions in Japanese companies.

He says Japan will have 30% of top positions filled by women by 2020 -- that's a challenging target, but one which Abe says can deliver big benefits.

He cites Arianna Huffington's quote about how Lehman Brothers would have survived if it had been Brothers and Sisters.

And adds that Hilary Clinton has told him that Japan's economy could grow 16% faster if women were fully engaged in it.

Abe declares:

Japan must become a place where women shine.

Updated at 5.37pm GMT

5.12pm GMT

The Japanese PM is gunning for special interests, saying that "I am willing to act like a drill bit to break through the solid rock of vested interests."

5.11pm GMT

Abe also pledges to keep shaking up the tax system.

5.10pm GMT

Abe: we are about to escape deflation

Abe begins by joking that he doesn't know who coined the term Abenomics, but he'll have to use his own name to describe his policiesfor a bit longer.

He then declares that Japan is poised to break free from the chronic deflation that has gripped it for so many years, declaring:

High wages, long overdue will lead to increased productivity.

Japan is now getting on track for fiscal consolidation, he adds.

Our growth rate has changed dramatically, from negative to positive, he continues, pointing to g to the Olympics and Paralympics coming soon.

A new dawn is breaking over Japan

Abe continues - we will liberalise the energy markets, and we will allow private firms to break into farming.

4.58pm GMT

Shinzo Abe is being introduced at Davos now, with WEF founder Klaus Schwab declaring that, thanks to his bold economic and monetary reforms, he can say that Japan is Back.

We need more bold ideas like Abenomics, Schwab adds.

4.55pm GMT

Bloomberg's Francine Lacqua has tweeted a great photo showing the aeroplanes on which the Israeli and Iranian delegations flew in for WEF -- side by side.

4.45pm GMT

It's nearly time for the big set-piece event of the day - a special address by Japan's prime minister, Shinzo Abe. The congress hall is filling up....

4.26pm GMT

Philip Jennings of UNI Global Union also believes some Davos delegates have woken up to the scale of the inequality problem gripping the global economy, saying:

They're now worried about social tensions, unemployment, and the unfair distribution of wealth.

The other important issue, he adds, is that the public have a complete lack of confidence that this generation's political classes understand the life of an ordinary worker.

4.13pm GMT

UNI: Pope Francis played a blinder at Davos

Just grabbed a few minute with Davos veteran Philip Jennings, general secretary of the UNI Global Union.

He's delighted that the Pope shook up Davos with a hard-hitting message last night to reflect on the causes of the economic crisis, and to help build a new economic order where wealth serves the people not the other way round (Larry Elliott has blogged about the Pope's 'leftie message' here).

It's Pope Francis's latest interjection into the debate on reforming capitalism - and Jennings reckons it has really made an impact on WEF this year, right at the start of the Forum, joking:

Our new Argentinian striker has delivered - he's scored a goal in the second minute of the game.

This year's Davos theme is all about reshaping the global economy -- and the Pope has thrown down the challenge to actually deliver, not just talk. Jennings explained:

If WEF were looking for a Papal blessing, then they didn't get it. They didn't get absolution either -- the message they got from the Pope was 'Do better, I'm watching'.

Updated at 4.15pm GMT

3.33pm GMT

Davos: Are the markets safer?

UK banking chiefs are telling Davos that the financial markets are safer than back in 2009, but not everyone is convinced they they've learned their lessons.

At a debate called "Are markets safer now", HSBC's chairman Douglas Flint said his bank had thrown much more resources at ensuring it is complying with the law.

Barclays boss Antony Jenkins argued that the issue goes beyond just banks.

Jill tweets the key points:

Paul Singer, CEO and co-chief investment officer of fund manager Elliott Management, is also on the panel -- and cautioned that banks are still involved in exotic products that could rebound on them:

Jenkins argues that the key is to keep bankers' animal spirits in check:

2.45pm GMT

Guinea's president: West's legal tricks helped steal our resources

Alpha Condé, president of Guinea, spoke at a session on mineral extraction a few minute ago, and accused Western lawyers of using trickery to steal natural resources from his country in the past.

He said the corrupt theft of natural resources was aided by the west, and its lawyers expertise in terms of legal tricks.

Conde said:

A lot of the transparency that was not present, was made possibly by legal tricks and the use of financial havens where people were able to hide their funds.

But he said the situation was now improving, as Guinea was getting support from the World Bank, the African Development Bank, and a number of western countries including the UK, the US, France and switzerland.

I am more optimistic about the situation, he concluded. 

(via Larry Elliott)

2.36pm GMT

3D printing has captured the attention of WEF delegates, with a large crowd forming to watch a demonstration of how the modelling and fabrication process works.

Neil Gershenfeld of the Fab Lab drew a cube on a screen, then a sphere, and used one to manipulate the shape of the other. He then niftily reshaped them, using a tool that was 'resisted' by the shapes to make a more intricate design. 

The gathering even attracted Sir Tim Berner-Lee, the father of the web, who positioned himself in front of the screen and took copious notes. Now there's a man who can spot an important technology....

2.14pm GMT

Bill Browder, the veteran hedge fund boss, has predicted that Vladimir Putin's government would collapse within a year if the price of oil fell to $60 a barrel. 

A barrel of Brent Crude is £107 a barrel, somewhat below the $117 figure oil-dependent Russia relies on to balance its budget.

Speaking to the Daily Telegraph in Davos, Browder described himself as "Putin's no 1 enemy". He has led a global campaign to bring to punish the top Kremlin officials he sees as responsible for the death of his lawyer, Sergei Magnitsky. (Background here).

All it will take is a fall in the price of oil to $60 a barrel and Putin will be gone within a year. You'd be surprised how brittle the system really is.

Browder also had a warning for investors piling into other fast-growing markets, the BRICs or Mints. 

Lot of ill-informed money went into these countries during the credit boom. The next big thing coming is that some of these countries will start to close their capital accounts. We're already seeing it in Egypt and Brazil in different ways.

This could start a chain-reaction, he said.

People will start asking themselves which country is next. Once this start people may find they can't get their money out again.

JR

Updated at 2.15pm GMT

1.58pm GMT

More on Vince Cable, with an intriguing report from Sky News that the business secretary plans to block a pay increase for the chief executive of the newly-privatised Royal Mail.

The row over pay has been simmering since last weekend, reports Sky, when Donald Brydon, Royal Mail's chairman, told the Sunday Telegraph that increasing Moya Greene's pay was necessary if the company wanted to keep her.

Describing her as the “lowest paid chief executive in the FTSE100”, he said:

I think it’s only fair to pay Moya the right market rate for her job.

Now Cable is said to be ready to use his vote to block any increase. This comes after Greene was forced to hand back a £250,000 housing allowance last year, prompting her to bemoan "the hopelessly broken" system for setting executive pay.

JR

Updated at 1.59pm GMT

1.52pm GMT

Oxfam: wealth inequality is immoral

Democratic dividend”, at least so far, is the catchiest phrase of the session on Africa in reference to the improved democracy across the continent (writes Jill Treanor).

Even so Oxfam's Winnie Byanyima took the opportunity to remind participants of the research put out the charity just as the WEF was beginning, that people are being trapped in a cycle of poverty.

“The 85 wealthiest people in the world own the same wealth as half the population of the world, there is something wrong with that because it is immoral."

Julian Roberts, boss of London-listed insurer Old Mutual, was sporting what looked to be a South African flag scarf, said he wouldn't be investing in Africa if there were not opportunities – 50% of the people are under 20. But there were problems – one infrastructure project Old Mutual funded was subsequently nationalised.

“Africa cannot exist without a handshake between private enterprise and the public sector,” said Roberts.

He also called for changes in visa requirements and import controls -pointing to the month it can take to get goods and services out of west Africa.

Aliko Dangote, a leading Nigerian businessman through his Dangote Group, lamented the lack of trade within Africa, currently just 11% of the total trade. As a Nigerian he said he needed 38 visas to move around the continent making it easier for Americans to move around and do business.

The president of Nigeria, Goodluck Elebe Jonathan, who was asked about the oil that “disappears” each year from the oil-rich Niger Delta. He insisted was not due to corruption. 

Updated at 2.36pm GMT

1.39pm GMT

Vince Cable has said the UK is seeing "spectacular improvements" to productivity in key manufacturing sectors, but faces "serious problem" if this was not spread more broadly across the economy. 

Speaking at the House of Common's business, innovation and skills select committee, the business secretary said productivity had to improve.

We have a serious problem if it continues but actually the poor productivity performance is a flipside of having a relatively favourable performance on employment.
We are working with some of the key industries - aerospace, cars, biosciences, supply chains for energy and others - and lot of the work around innovation and skill training and supply chain rebuilding is about improving British productivity. 

You are now seeing spectacular improvements in productivity in some of those key manufacturing sectors. It hasn't happened through the rest of the economy.

I've taken quotes from the Press Association.

1.33pm GMT

A couple more photos from this morning's sessions

1.26pm GMT

The Office for Budget Responsibility has issued its comment on figures showing a drop in government borrowing.

The implicit message for the chancellor is 'don't celebrate too soon'.

The 2013-14 PSNB [Public Sector Net Borrowing] forecast remains uncertain. Tax receipts will depend in part on the performance of the economy over the remainder of the year, but there are additional uncertainties, such as the tax expected from financial sector bonuses and the extent to which receipts from self-assessment (SA) income tax are affected by the reduction in the additional rate of income tax to 45p.

And on the spending side, much will depend on departments’ surrenders of underspends in their supplementary estimates (usually published in February) and the extent to which those estimates are in turn underspent. Central and local government monthly expenditure outturns are also prone to revision well after the end of the financial year.

Worth bearing in mind, because the ONS figures are estimates subject to revision.

JR

1.14pm GMT

Branson: war on drugs has failed

Sir Richard Branson has been taking part at another lunch event, on the 2030 agenda for progress in the developing world.

It was billed as a private lunch, but some details are being tweeted -- with the Telegraph's Kamal Ahmed reporting that Branson called for penalties for drugs offences to be relaxed:

Oxfam's Greenpeace International Executive Director, Kumi Naidoo, was also on the panel and reports that Branson called on Davos attendees to "replace dirty business with clean business".

Matt Damon and Gary White of Water.org were also attending-- last night, Damon explained that they hope to raise money in Davos today to fund more micro loans to people in the developing world who need a supply of clean water.

1.05pm GMT

Gilt yields continue to rise after jobless data

Gilt yields have continued to climb after the big fall in UK unemployment. At 12:30 they were up six basis points at 2.895%. The rise took the spread between British and German interest rates to its widest in more than eight years, Reuters reported.

Investors are betting on a rate rise in the UK whereas talk in the eurozone is of whether the ECB will loosen monetary policy. Hence the widening gap between the rate investors will accept to buy UK and German government bonds in the market.

Sterling rose to a one-year high against the euro, too.

Economists at Citi have moved their target date for a UK rate rise to the final quarter of this year from their earlier forecast of the second quarter of 2015.

Plenty there for the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee to ponder.

SF

12.54pm GMT

Davos: Global economy nothing to shout about.

There wasn't much jubilation among the Davos panel at the session on the Global Financial Outlook this morning. Ray Dalio, founder of Bridgewater Associates, said the US economy has hit a dull rut, and also predicted that emerging markets will suffer as capital continues to flow out.

Joe Weisenthal of Business Insider tweeted the key points:

And Standard Chartered CEO Peter Sands echoed a point being made in the session on the European recovery - May's elections could change the picture:

12.49pm GMT

Jennifer has handed over to me, Sean Farrell, for a while. I wrote the Greece post just now.

12.47pm GMT

Greek court strikes down wage cuts

Greece's highest administrative court has overruled pay cuts for the police and armed forces imposed by the government in 2012, Reuters reports.

The decision could create a €500m gap in the country's finances, causing further complications for talks between Greece and its lenders over more rescue loans, the report said.

The ruling hasn't been made public but was confirmed by officials, Reuters said. The 10% cut was judged unconstitutional because as a core part of the state they warrant protection, an official told the agency.

SF

Updated at 12.48pm GMT

12.34pm GMT

Even the powerbrokers of Davos stop for lunch, and today they're tucking into a buffet feast hosted by the government of Nigeria (writes GW, on a laptop propped up on a pile of mangos and pineapples). 

Much bantering is taking place between delegates, while a looped video hails Nigeria's many economic opportunities (a growing middle class, big oil reserves etc). No mention of human rights concerns, alas.

Updated at 1.27pm GMT

12.26pm GMT

Shrugging off the latest fall in unemployment, the FTSE 100 index is down 0.08% at 6828 points.

According to Reuters, this marks a step back from an 8-month peak, with companies unsettled about rate rises.

JR

12.13pm GMT

Nouriel Roubini, the economist who forecast that a housing slump would cause an economic crash, is making more eye-catching predictions at Davos.

JR

Updated at 12.43pm GMT

12.00pm GMT

That session on whether Europe was "back" from the brink of crisis ended with Accenture's top man in France, Pierre Nanterme, criticising Europe's leaders for fueling extremist political groups.

 Nanterme said he was "extremely concerned" about the European elections, given the rise of extreme parties in Europe riding on the back of record unemployment.

He said European leaders and policymakers were to blame for failing to address people's fears over inequality and employment, issues that are "entirely absent" from the technical debate about Europe.

People "want a job, they want inclusion and diversity within Europe", Nanterme said.

11.45am GMT

Trade Union leaders have welcomed the fall in UK unemployment, but sounded notes of caution.

Frances O’Grady, general secretary of the TUC, described the big fall in unemployment as encouraging.

But while headline unemployment is within a whisker of the Bank’s forward guidance threshold, an early interest rate rise would clobber mortgage holders and businesses – jeopardising our economic recovery.

Patchy levels of jobs growth in parts of the north and the continuing squeeze on living standards should make the Bank of England think twice before considering a rate raise.

The TUC’s latest economic report found that the likelihood of being in work has fallen in the North East, North West, West Midlands and South West since mid-2010, despite the number of people in work increasing by around 780,000 across the UK.

Len McCluskey, Unite's general secretary, had a message for the Low Pay Commission, soon to issue its recommendations on the minimum wage.

 Britain’s workers need a decent pay rise so that wages are not continually eroded by inflation. Unite has repeatedly called for the national minimum wage to be raised by £1.50 an hour from the current £6.31 – and we urge the Low Pay Commission to make that recommendation. 

To put in it perspective, the UK has one of the highest rates of personal debt in Europe, millions are working for poverty wages and thousands of people rely on food banks to put a meal on the table for their family, yet the stock market is performing well. Companies can well afford to be more generous when it comes to paying more to their workers.

JR

11.41am GMT

The former Cabinet secretary Lord Gus O'Donnell is in Davos trying to raise awareness about mental health.

O'Donnell heads the WEF's council on well being and mental health, and says policy makers and business need to tackle the issue.

He told Larry Elliott that:

"One in four members of the workforce suffers from some of mental health problem and the benefits of picking up problems early are considerable. Problems are treatable."

O'Donnell says there are three big benefits of early action: a much-smaller NHS bill for anti-depressants; fewer people on disability benefits and preventing people from losing precious employment skills.

"This is a big issue, but nobody talks about it", he added.

Updated at 11.48am GMT

11.32am GMT

Over in Brussels, the EU executive has called on Europe to cut its carbon emissions by 40% by 2030, compared to 1990 levels.

The 40% target still has to be written into law, a lengthy process that involves the EU's 28 member states and the European Parliament. The European Commission has also called for a 27% of Europe's energy to come from renewable energy by 2030, and for energy savings of 25%.

For full coverage go to the Guardian's environment blog.

JR

11.18am GMT

The politics of interest-rate decisions...

JR

Updated at 11.18am GMT

11.11am GMT

Amid all the drama over the unemployment data, let's not overlook an improvement in the UK public finances.

Government borrowing fell to £12.1bn in December, down £2.1bn from last year. The figure excludes bank bailouts.

You can see the full Office for National Statistics data set here.

JR

Updated at 11.11am GMT

11.08am GMT

Sir Tim Berners-Lee made a surprise intervention "from the floor" into a Davos debate about Big Brother and a conversation about haystacks – bundles of data being collected by the governments, reports Jill Treanor.

"When you are operating at this level you have no idea if these people are American citizens or been suspected of committing some sort of crime,” the father of the web said.

Unemployment is falling fast. In the quarter ending in November, the jobless total saw its biggest drop since modern records began. The jobless rate is currently 7.1% and will hit the Bank of England’s threshold for contemplating an interest rate rise next month.

 Does this mean that Threadneedle Street seriously underestimated the strength of the labour market? Yes it does. Will Mark Carney have to announce a change to the Bank’s forward guidance strategy next month? Yes he will. Is an increase in the cost of borrowing imminent? No it isn’t.

Harvard professor Ken Rogoff does pay credit to Europe's politicians for being "light years" ahead of Washington in realising the scale of the problem in inequality,and the labour force's shrinking share of the pie.

More progressive taxation will be needed to rebalance the situation, he suggests. And if Europe takes too long to tackle its problems, it may wake up from its slumbers to find it's a lot smaller in globaal terms.

10.46am GMT

Following a larger than expected fall in unemployment, economists are not expecting a change to interest rates anytime soon.

Jeremy Cook, chief economist at currency company World First, thinks the odds are against a rate rise, for "three good reasons".

  •  The Bank of England has been eager in these minutes to emphasise that productivity growth has been ‘disappointing’. They will likely use this as a reason for keeping policy very loose despite unemployment falling below the 7% threshold alongside.
  •  Wages – despite the recent anecdotal data from PMIs and some companies, especially in the services sector, that wage pressure is building we are still waiting for the 3m average to get back above 1.0% let alone CPI at 2.0%. Rate hikes are unlikely to be popular in an environment of falling real wages.
  •  Lastly, we’re looking at the pound. The Bank of England has expressed concerns of late in the run higher of GBP. Moves to raise rates and tighten policy will be a shot in the arm for an already overvalued currency; a killer for any ‘export-driven-march-of-the-makers’.

In a killer line, he adds:

As it stands at the moment forward guidance is proving to be exactly what everyone believes it to be; a policy that allows for further loose monetary policy and reflation of a credit bubble.

Samuel Tombs at Capital Economics, agrees there will be no rate rise.

We think that there is a strong chance that the Committee will alter its forward guidance alongside next month’s inflation report in order to provide the recovery with more support. 

Howard Archer at IHS, thinks unemployment is unlikely to improve at such a fast pace in future.

The recent rate of improvement in the labour market has been both impressive and surprising, but we are dubious that unemployment will keep falling at such a rapid rate...

We also anticipate that employment growth will increasingly be limited by increasing productivity as many companies are able to make greater use of the workers they already have. The fall in the unemployment is also likely to be limited by an expanding labour pool and by further job losses in the public sector. The workforce is expected to be lifted by some people returning to the jobs market as the overall improved economic environment makes them more optimistic about getting jobs.

It may also be that a significant number of more confident companies are now taking on workers earlier than they really need them – in anticipation that the UK really is set for a period of sustained, healthy growth, and to ensure that they get potentially the best staff available. If this a significant factor, it would also suggest that the growth in employment will moderate over the coming months.

He also thinks interest rates will stay unchanged at 0.5% until mid 2015.

Axel Weber hammers home his point about Europe's weak recovery, saying that the speed at which it's now growing "still feels like a crisis".

He told a packed room at Davos (highlights start here) that:

The economy is too weak to sustain the kind of growth in jobs we need to get out of this crisis.

10.27am GMT

Europe is also vulnerable to cutting-edge technologies such as 3D printing, Sorrell warns, which allow companies to cut their workforces.

10.27am GMT

The Bank of England is getting a fair bit of stick for its dodgy economic forecasting.

The shifting economic data puts the bank's forward guidance policy under strain - a pledge to hold interest rates until unemployment falls to 7%.

The bank now says there is no immediate need to raise interest rates, even if unemployment falls to 7%.

From the minutes of the monetary policy committee:

Looking beyond the immediate policy decision, the Committee noted that while the recovery was becoming more firmly entrenched, productivity growth had been disappointing, and unemployment had fallen faster than expected. Inflation had returned to the 2% target, however, and cost pressures were subdued. Members therefore saw no immediate need to raise Bank Rate even if the 7% unemployment threshold were to be reached in the near future. Moreover, it was likely that the headwinds to growth associated with the aftermath of the financial crisis would persist for some time yet and that inflationary pressures would remain contained. Consequently when the time did come to raise Bank Rate, it would be appropriate to do so only gradually. 

The MPC also points out that weak pay growth "pointed to the continued existence of slack in the labour market". So unemployment has some way further to fall.

Weber: Euro elections and stress tests are risks for 2014

Axel Weber of UBS (ex-Bundesbank) says the risks facing Europe have receded, but the region could face new upheaval this year.

 European growth rates are too weak, he warns, saying:

The mood in financial markets may have improved, but the economic situation in many European countries will not improve.

Weber says there are two threats -- May's European elections which could see more extremist parties enter the European Parliament, and possibly act like the US Tea Party....

...and Europe's upcoming asset quality review (stress-testing eurozone banks).

That test is meant to be an exam, and to be a credible exam someone needs to fail it, argues Weber. That could lead to market turbulence as speculators try to bet which banks will be winners or losers.

Ken Rogoff tells Davos that the easing of the eurozone crisis is the single biggest reason for the pick-up in the global economy.

But the "really horrific" youth unemployment stats are a big worry - Europe is an aging society, and it's losing the valuable resource of its youth.

Sir Martin Sorrell and Ken Rogoff have agreed that Europe is stronger than a year ago, but still faces deep problems -- particularly its youth unemployment crisis.

Sorrell told the "Is Europe Back?" session that he was "very bullish" about Germany and Poland, and also Russia. The IMF's new forecasts (yesterday) also give hope to George Osborne and David Cameron ahead of next year's election.

"The bookends of Europe", UK and Germany, are doing well, says Sorrell.

But three countries worry him - France (still on the downstroke of the U, says Sorrell), Italy (bumping on the bottom) and Spain (on the upturn, but with unacceptably high levels of unemployment).

Sorrell adds:

You cannot have a situation where 50% of your young people are out of work... it is politically and socially unacceptable.

Tech CEOs tell Davos that NSA affair shows need for changes

As promised - here's the story of how several technology CEOs have told Davos that fundamental legal changes need to be made in the light of the Edward Snowden/NSA revelations.

Jill Treanor reports from this morning's session on "The New Digital Context"

The boss of BT admitted on Wednesday that customers could not be guaranteed 100% privacy when using the internet or mobile devices and called for changes to “murky” laws on data collection.

Speaking at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Gavin Patterson addressed the issues throw into open by the Guardian's investigation into the NSA through the whistleblower Edward Snowden.

Asked if he wanted more laws, Patterson, who became the boss of BT recently, said: “Exactly, making it clear. It's just too murky at the moment it needs to be transparent and needs to be clear guidelines about what's acceptable and what isn't, Paterson said.

“The legislation has to catch up . This is a challenge for the many different parts of our business models, it's often several years behind. It's not fit for purpose today. Everybody recognises the internet plays a role in protection us and we've got to make sure it's not intrusive and also protects the rights to the individual. I don't think the legislation has managed to keep up”.

Could there be 100% privacy? “I think that's unlikely and I think that's [would mean] zero security,” Patterson.

President Barack Obama on Friday announced reforms to the NSA, ending government storage of phone data and sparking fresh debate about the way data is collected.

Marissa Mayer, the boss of Yahoo, told attendees in Davos it should be clear what data is being disclosed.

She said:

“What's murky about some of what is happing today is people don't necessary know what data is being collected and about what is being used.".

She added that “2014 will be a tipping point.... it will change everyone's daily routines very fundamentally".

The chairman and chief executive of Cisco, John Chambers, called for co-operation. He said:

“We're not a service provider...we don't share our code with anyone. We come at it from a different perspective. We need rules of the road that everyone can live with... We need all companies to come up with general guidelines....

Countries need to work together to solve these issues, he said.

The billionaire philanthropist thinks there will be almost no poor countries left in the world by 2035.

More than 70% of countries will have a higher income than China does today, while child mortality in developing countries will fall sharply.

In the Gates Foundation's annual letter, he and his wife Melinda, tackle head on "the myth that poor countries are doomed to stay poor.

I am optimistic enough about this that I am willing to make a prediction. By 2035, there will be almost no poor countries left in the world. (I mean by our current definition of poor*). Almost all countries will be what we now call lower-middle income or richer. Countries will learn from their most productive neighbours and benefit from innovations like new vaccines, better seeds, and the digital revolution. Their labour forces, buoyed by expanded education, will attract new investments.

*Specifically, I mean that by 2035, almost no country will be as poor as any of the 35 countries that the World Bank classifies as low-income today, even after adjusting for inflation.

A few countries will be held back by war, politics (North Korea, barring a big change there), or geography (landlocked nations in central Africa). And inequality will still be a problem: There will be poor people in every region.

More than 70% of countries will have a higher per-person income than China does today. Nearly 90% will have a higher income than India does today.

 The Gates couple also identify two other myths about poverty.

Bill Gates is concerned that the notion that “foreign aid is a waste of money”, which he says is often based on anecdotal evidence, and gives governments an excuse to slash aid budgets.

[Aid] saves and improves lives very effectively, laying the groundwork for the kind of long-term economic progress

The third myth the couple identify is that "saving lives leads to overpopulation". "This kind of thinking has gotten the world into a lot of trouble," writes Melinda Gates.

Union leader Philip Jennings, who heads up UNI Global Union, has been criticising the sinners of the world economy in CNBC's TV studio. He tweets his best lines:

CNBC is excited by Marissa Mayer's declaration that mobile traffic will have overtaken PC traffic by the end of the year.
